SENT.plain: Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genomic imprinting disease secondary to the loss of a functional paternal copy of 15q11-q13
Unlike its related imprinting disorder, Angelman syndrome, PWS has not been regarded as a risk factor for epilepsy
A retrospective analysis of 92 patients with PWS identified 24 (26%) with seizures
Twenty-two of these (92%) were affected by focal epilepsy and only two (8%) had generalized epilepsy
The most common seizure type was staring spells (67%)
Correlation to genotype analysis showed deletions were more common in patients with epilepsy than in patients without epilepsy
The epilepsy syndromes were easy to control with a single antiepileptic drug in most cases
Three patients (11%) had had febrile seizures
These findings suggest that PWS may be a risk factor for epilepsy, which can manifest with focal features

Patients with PWS with a deletion genotype showed a trend toward developing seizures compared with patients with other genotypes in our series, even though this difference did not achieve statistical significance
